Access to capital is a key piece of the puzzle for any small-cap trying to advance multiple advanced materials and energy projects at once.  

HPQ Silicon has announced a non-brokered private placement that, if fully subscribed, would provide funding to support working capital, its silicon-based battery material pilot plant, and ongoing hydrogen-related development work. For those watching cleantech and battery materials, this is an example of how companies are structuring financing to move R&D and pilot projects forward without going through brokers.  

HPQ Silicon announces non-brokered private placement offering of up to $3M CAD  

@HPQ_Silicon $HPQ / $HPQFF  

‚Ä¢ Offering of up to 18,181,819 units at $0.165 CAD per unit, for aggregate gross proceeds of up to approximately $3M CAD  
‚Ä¢ Each unit consists of 1 common share and 1 non-transferable common share purchase warrant  
‚Ä¢ Each warrant is exercisable at $0.25 CAD for 24 months from the closing date of the offering  
‚Ä¢ The Company may pay up to a 6% cash commission and issue up to 6% in finders‚Äô warrants to certain eligible finders  
‚Ä¢ Net proceeds are intended to be used for working capital, accelerating execution of the Company‚Äôs Silicon-Based Battery Material pilot plant project, and continuing development of the Company‚Äôs hydrogen-based projects, subject to final TSXV acceptance  

For those following advanced materials, battery tech, and hydrogen: what do you typically look at when evaluating a non-brokered private placement like this (structure, use of proceeds, stage of projects, or something else)?

Progress Continues Toward Ring of Fire Access

@CanadaChrome | $CACR

Ontario First Nations have completed accelerated environmental assessments for key road segments connecting to the mineral-rich Ring of Fire region in northern Ontario.

‚Ä¢ Marten Falls First Nation submitted its environmental assessment for an access road linking the region to Ontario‚Äôs highway network

‚Ä¢ Webequie First Nation completed its assessment earlier this year

‚Ä¢ Ontario and the federal government continue coordinating oversight as the province advances plans to begin construction as early as August 2026

Incremental but meaningful progress toward unlocking northern Ontario‚Äôs critical mineral potential in partnership with First Nations.

Why This Matters for The Canadian Chrome Company

‚Ä¢ The company holds chromite interests connected to the broader Ring of Fire region where transportation access has historically been a key development hurdle

‚Ä¢ Progress toward permanent road infrastructure could improve long-term logistics and overall project economics across the district

‚Ä¢ Advancing access strengthens the investment case for Canadian critical mineral development, including chrome used in stainless steel and industrial supply chains

A steady infrastructure build-out is often what turns mineral districts from geological potential into economic reality.

Titanium 3D printing is moving from niche to strategic, and the supply of high-spec powders is becoming a key piece of the aerospace innovation puzzle.

PyroGenesis has confirmed its first titanium metal powder order with a Scientific Aerospace Research Organization based in Europe, using its NexGen plasma atomization process to provide material for advanced electron beam melting (EBM) research. This reflects an example of an aerospace research group working directly with a specialized powder producer to support additive manufacturing R&D.

First titanium powder contract with European aerospace research organization confirmed

@PyroGenesis_Inc $PYR / $PYRGF

‚Ä¢ Contract signed to supply "coarse" cut Ti64 powder (45‚Äì106¬µm) produced by PyroGenesis‚Äô NexGen plasma atomization system

‚Ä¢ Customer is a Scientific Aerospace Research Organization based in Europe that supports innovation for the region‚Äôs aerospace industry

‚Ä¢ Powder will be used in electron beam melting (EBM) manufacturing as part of aerospace R&D programs

‚Ä¢ This is PyroGenesis‚Äô first contract with this organization and first order for this specific 45‚Äì106¬µm particle size range

‚Ä¢ Management notes this expands both the company‚Äôs aerospace customer base and the range of titanium powders it supplies, in a market where titanium 3D printing powders are projected to grow from $214M in 2023 to $1.4B by 2032

For those tracking aerospace and metal 3D printing: how important is it for research organizations and OEMs to work directly with specialized powder producers when qualifying new materials and particle sizes for critical applications?
